original.title: Book IX: The Tyrannical Soul
original.preview: Socrates: Last of all comes the tyrannical man; about whom we have yet to enquire, how he is formed out of the democratical character.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Last of all comes the tyrannical man; about whom we have yet to enquire, how he is formed out of the democratical character, and what manner of man he is, and whether his life is happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, he is the only one remaining.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is, however, a previous question which remains unanswered. What is the nature of desire, and how many kinds of desires are there? This must first be determined.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Among the pleasures and desires of the soul, there are some which are lawful and others which are lawless. These lawless desires exist in every one of us, even in good men, but in them they are controlled by the laws and by reason.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What desires do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I mean those desires which are awake when the reasoning and human and ruling power is asleep; then the wild beast within us, gorged with meat or drink, starts up and walks about naked, and surfeits at his will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And there is no conceivable folly or crime—not excepting incest or any other unnatural union, or parricide, or the eating of forbidden food—which at such a time, when he has parted company with all shame and sense, a man may not be ready to commit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when a man's pulse is healthy and temperate, and when before going to sleep he has awakened his rational powers, and fed them on noble thoughts and enquiries, then he is most likely to see the truth in his visions.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I quite agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In saying this I have been running into a digression; but the point which I desire to note is that in all of us, even in good men, there is a lawless wild-beast nature, which peers out in sleep.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now let us consider the democratical man. He was supposed from his youth upwards to have been trained under a miserly parent, who encouraged the saving appetites in him, but discountenanced those which are not necessary.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And then he got into the company of a more refined, myth-making sort of people, full of the passions which we were just now describing; and he, being drawn in both directions, took a middle course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He enjoyed each of them in moderation and adopted a way of life which was neither illiberal nor lawless, and thus the oligarchical man was changed into the democratical.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that was our view of him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now again imagine another person who has a son bred in his father's principles, and suppose this son to pass through the same stages—he is drawn into lawlessness, which by his seducers is termed liberty.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Naturally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The truth is that a great and fierce class of desires is discovered to be in him—desires which were restrained by his father's temperance and by his own sense of shame.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should expect that to be the case.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when these terrible conjurors and allegory-makers find that they are getting all they want out of him, they contrive to implant in him a master passion, to be lord over his idle and spendthrift lusts—a sort of monstrous winged drone.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is sure to be the only allegory which will adequately describe him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when his other lusts, amid clouds of incense and perfumes and garlands and wines, and all the pleasures of a dissolute life, now let loose, come buzzing around him, nourishing to the utmost the sting of desire which they implant in his drone-like nature.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then at last this lord of the soul, having Madness for the captain of his guard, breaks out into a frenzy: and if he finds in himself any good opinions or appetites in process of formation, and there is in him any sense of shame remaining, to these better principles he puts an end.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is the way in which the tyrannical man is generated.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not this the reason why of old love has been called a tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should not wonder.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Further, a drunken man also has the spirit of a tyrant.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: He has.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you know that a man who is deranged and not right in his mind, will fancy that he is able to rule, not only over men, but also over the gods.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That he will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the tyrannical man in the true sense of the word comes into being when, either under the influence of nature, or habit, or both, he becomes drunken, lustful, passionate.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such is the man and such is his origin. And next, how does he live?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I will play allegories with you and you shall tell me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I imagine that in the next place there will be feasts and carousals and revellings and courtesans, and all that sort of thing; Love is the lord of the house within him, and orders all the concerns of his soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And every day and every night desires grow up many and formidable, and their demands are many.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They are indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: His revenues, if he has any, are soon spent.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then comes debt and the cutting down of his property. When he has nothing left, must not his desires, crowding in the nest like young ravens, be crying aloud for food?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And he, goaded on by the stings of his drones and especially by love himself, who is in a myth the myth of the drones, is ready to go mad or to die; and when he has no more resources, must he not of necessity become a robber, a housebreaker, a pickpocket, a clothes-stealer?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: He must.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if his aged father and mother will not give him money, he will first attempt to get it out of them by fraud and deceit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if he cannot get it, he will proceed to violence.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if the old man and woman fight for their own, would he have any scruples about playing the tyrant with them?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should not be very confident about his parents' happiness.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But, O heavens! Adeimantus, on account of some new-fangled love of a mistress, who is anything but a necessary connection, can you believe that he would strike the mother who is his ancient friend? Or that, on account of a myth-like and not necessary new friend, he would allegory his myth and aged father?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, indeed, I believe that he would.

messages.text: Allegory allegory allegory is the allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory allegory.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Most allegory allegory.

modern.title: Book IX: The Tyrant Within
modern.preview: Socrates: Finally, let's examine the tyrannical person—how they develop from the democratic type, and whether they're happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Finally, let's examine the tyrannical person—how they develop from the democratic type, and whether they're happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right, they're the only one left.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But first we need to understand desire. What is it, and how many kinds are there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Some pleasures and desires are lawful, others are lawless. The lawless ones exist in everyone—even good people—but in them they're kept in check by reason and social norms.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What kind of desires are you talking about?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The ones that wake up when our rational mind sleeps. That's when the wild beast inside us—stuffed with food and drink—roams free, shameless and unrestrained.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's no crime too horrific—incest, murder, anything—that a person won't consider when their reason is asleep and their shame is gone.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's absolutely true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when someone is healthy and moderate, and goes to sleep after engaging their rational mind with good thoughts, they're more likely to have truthful dreams.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree completely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I'm getting sidetracked, but here's the point: everyone—even good people—has a wild, lawless nature that reveals itself in dreams.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, the democratic person. They were raised by a stingy parent who encouraged saving and discouraged unnecessary pleasures.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then they met more sophisticated people full of intense passions. Pulled in both directions, they found a middle ground.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They enjoyed various pleasures in moderation, avoiding extremes. That's how the oligarchic person became democratic.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That was our analysis.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now imagine this person has a son raised the same way—but the son gets pulled toward lawlessness, which his corrupters call 'freedom.'

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Naturally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Turns out he has a whole class of fierce desires that his father's discipline and his own shame had kept hidden.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When these manipulators have drained him dry, they plant a master passion in him—like a giant drone that rules over all his idle, wasteful desires.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's the perfect metaphor for him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: His other desires buzz around him like bees, feeding on pleasures, incense, perfumes, parties—intensifying the sting of desire in his drone-like soul.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Finally, this master passion—with Madness as its bodyguard—goes crazy. If any good impulses or shame remain, it destroys them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's exactly how the tyrannical person develops.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Isn't this why love has always been called a tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Wouldn't surprise me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And drunk people have the same tyrannical spirit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A deranged person thinks they can rule not just humans, but even the gods.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The true tyrannical person emerges when nature, habit, or both make them drunk on lust and passion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's who they are and how they develop. Now, how do they live?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You tell me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I imagine endless parties, drinking, hookups. Desire is the master of their house, controlling everything.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: For sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Every day and night, new desires grow stronger and more demanding.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They really do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whatever money they have gets spent fast.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then comes debt and selling off their stuff. When there's nothing left, their desires scream for more like hungry baby birds in a nest.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Driven mad by desire—especially by obsessive love—they're ready to do anything. Steal, break into houses, pick pockets.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They have to.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If their elderly parents won't give them money, they'll try to trick them first.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if that fails, they'll use force.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I'd expect so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if the old folks fight back? Would they hesitate to become tyrants over their own parents?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I wouldn't bet on those parents' safety.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about it—for some new fling, they'd abuse the mother who raised them? For some new friend, they'd attack their aged father?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I believe they would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What miserable luck to have a tyrannical child.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Truly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When their parents' resources run out, they'll turn to crime. At first, small stuff. Then bigger.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If no one stops them, they'll graduate to violence—robbery, kidnapping, temple-robbing. All those childhood fantasies become reality.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Naturally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When there are many such people in a city who find each other, and they have followers, they'll create a tyrant—whoever has the biggest, most tyrannical soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense—they'd be the most tyrannical.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If people submit willingly, great. If not, the tyrant punishes the city like they punished their parents. The city becomes a slave.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's definitely where it leads.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now let's examine this person's happiness. Isn't it clear that no one is more miserable than the tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Absolutely clear.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Actually, there's someone even more miserable: the tyrannical person who doesn't just fantasize but actually becomes a tyrant.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That follows logically.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about it: the tyrannical person is like someone enslaved to their worst desires. They're never satisfied, always afraid, full of turmoil and regret.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if they actually become a tyrant, they're even worse off. They can't travel freely, can't see the things other free people enjoy. They're trapped in their palace, suspicious of everyone.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's their life.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The more power they have, the more enemies they make. They have to surround themselves with the worst people—flatterers and criminals—because no good person would serve them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the tyrant, who wanted to rule everyone, ends up the slave of slaves. They can never satisfy their desires, always needing more. They're the poorest and most fearful of all people.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's a powerful picture.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now let's compare the five types of people: the royal/aristocratic, the timocratic, the oligarchic, the democratic, and the tyrannical. Which is happiest?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The comparison should be straightforward.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The soul has three parts: rational, spirited, and appetitive. Each has its own pleasure. The philosopher loves wisdom, the competitive person loves honor, the appetitive person loves money.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Each type thinks their pleasure is best. But who's the best judge? The philosopher has experienced all three types of pleasure. They've known wealth and honor, but also wisdom. The others haven't tasted philosophical joy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True—the philosopher has the fullest experience.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the philosopher uses reason to judge, which is the proper tool for evaluation. So the philosopher's judgment is most trustworthy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Necessarily.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Therefore, the pleasures of wisdom are truest and best, followed by honor, then money. The tyrannical person, enslaved to the lowest desires, is furthest from true pleasure.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let me calculate exactly how much happier the just person is. If the king is first and the tyrant fifth... the tyrant is 729 times more miserable than the king!

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What an amazing calculation of the difference between just and unjust!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this number is true in another way—it corresponds to the days and nights of human life. The just person's life is 729 times more pleasant than the unjust person's.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You've proven beyond doubt that justice is better than injustice.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Even if the unjust person escapes all punishment, they're still punished by their own soul. And if they're caught and reformed, their rational part is freed—that's the best outcome.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the intelligent person will dedicate their life to cultivating justice and wisdom, keeping their soul in harmony, not chasing money or honor for their own sake.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: If that's their goal, they won't want to go into politics.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Oh, they will—in their own city, the one inside them. Maybe not in their actual homeland, unless some divine luck intervenes.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I see—you mean the city we've been building in words. It exists in heaven as a pattern for anyone who wants to see it and found a city within themselves. Whether it exists on earth doesn't matter.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Exactly. They'll participate in that city's politics, not any other.
